questions.question: We have all heard about cyber violence and cyberbullying, but do you really know what differentiates them?
options: Cyber violence is an isolated act, while cyberbullying is repeated.
Cyberbullying becomes cyber violence when it is too violent.
questions.explanation: When an act of cyber violence is repeated over and over, it is called cyberbullying. These acts can include insults, threats, or sharing private content without consent.

questions.question: Young people are increasingly exposed to digital dangers, but what age group is most affected by cyberbullying?
questions.explanation: About 60% of 18-25 year-olds report having been victims of cyberbullying.

questions.question: Young people are not only victims of cyberbullying; some participate in it. How many teens or children admit to having cyberbullied someone online?
questions.explanation: 73% of women have experienced online violence, including insults, threats, or harassment.
questions.source: Source: Second volume of the Health Behavior in School-aged Children (HBSC) survey on forms of bullying and violence among adolescents in 44 countries and regions published by WHO.

questions.question: What percentage of 18-25 year-olds claim to have been victims of cyberbullying?
questions.explanation: 60% of 18-25 year-olds report having been victims of cyberbullying.
questions.source: Source: Online study conducted by Audirep for Caisse d’Epargne and E-enfance between May 8 and June 3, 2022, among a sample of 1,209 young people aged 18 to 25.

questions.question: Victims of cyberbullying are often women. But do you have any idea of the percentage of affected women?
questions.explanation: 85% of women have experienced online violence, including insults, threats, or harassment.
questions.source: Source: Study 'Measuring the prevalence of online violence against women' - the Economist Intelligence Unit published in 2021.

questions.question: Often, online harassment goes beyond the screen. Do you know how many victims end up being threatened in real life?
questions.explanation: For 71% of victims, cyberbullying continues offline!
questions.source: Source: ADL NGO report 'Hate is No Game: Harassment and Positive Social Experiences in Online Games' 2021.

questions.question: A friend or relative tells you about threatening messages and insults they are receiving. What number can they contact?
questions.explanation: 3018, managed by the e-Enfance association, is the number to call in case of cyberbullying. A free and anonymous service that helps victims and witnesses.

questions.question: You come across shocking and illegal content online, what do you do?
options: Report it on Pharos, a platform for combating cyberbullying and inappropriate content.
You comment on the content saying it has no place on the internet.
questions.explanation: Pharos is THE platform to report illegal content. It is a quick and secure way to remove harmful and unhealthy content.

questions.question: What penalty does an adult risk in case of online moral harassment?
options: 2 years in prison and a €30,000 fine
A 6-month ban from the platform from which the offense was committed.

questions.question: 48% of gamers are actually female gamers. How many of them adopt strategies to conceal their gender to avoid being harassed?
questions.explanation: 40% of female gamers adopt strategies, such as choosing a male username or refusing to participate in voice chats, to avoid inappropriate comments.
questions.source: Source: Study conducted by IFOP for GamerTop.fr from March 17 to 23, 2023, through a self-administered questionnaire among a sample of 5,009 people, representative of the French population aged over 15.
